Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Story: My phone buzzes in my apron pocket just as I’m finishing up Mrs. Lee’s trim. It’s my mom, right on schedule for our weekly call. I glance at the clock—if I answer now, I’ll be late for my next client, but if I wait, I’ll miss the window when Mom is free. Mrs. Lee, always cheerful, suddenly frowns at her reflection and asks if I can snip just a bit more off her fringe. She’s never complained before, and I know how important it is to make sure she leaves happy. My hands hover over her hair, scissors poised, but my mind is split. I can hear my mom’s voice in my head, expecting to catch up, to hear about my week, to tell me about Dad’s new hobby. At the same time, I feel the weight of Mrs. Lee’s trust in me as her hairdresser. I want to be the attentive daughter who never misses a call, and the professional who never lets a client down. My heart pounds as I stare at the phone, torn between two worlds, both needing me right now.
